directions.Direction: Blend honeydew until smooth liquid
Add sugar, corn syrup, vodka, lemon juice, salt blend until dissolved
Strain into a bowl. Optional: pour in kombucha and stir to combine (I add this in to balance the sweetness and because my friends made fun of me).
Pour into Ninja containers (I pour any extra into a deli container). Freeze overnight or until the mixture is frozen solid
Blend on sorbet setting (4 minutes). Enjoy immediately.

Creator: alchenny
Name: Honeydew Melon Sorbet (made with Ninja Creami)
Description:
As I was sipping a Truly on a warm darty day, this idea came into my head. This recipe highlights the overlooked honeydew melon and turning it into a refreshing summer sorbet.

Served as a palette cleanser at my student-run pop-up restaurant with some agar water jelly and lemon microbasil.

directions.Direction: In a saucepan or microwave, melt butter.
combine butter with sugar, flour, water, and cocoa nibs. If the batter is too thick, add a small splash of liquid.
Rest in the fridge for at least 30 minutes.
Preheat over to 400F/200C.
Make teaspoon sized balls and bake for 5-8 minutes until the tuiles are a light golden brown.
Remove from the oven. If tuiles are slightly misshapen, reshape with a round cookie cutter.

Creator: alchenny
Name: Cocoa Nib Tuile Recipe
Description:
A fancy, snappy, and thin cookie to make fancy desserts or to "eat like their pringles" -- my roommate

Notes:
Cocoa nibs can be omitted completed or substituted for sesame seeds

directions.Direction: Preheat oven to 325F/180C
Over high heat bring water to simmer with cardamon pods and tea bag.
Pour in cocoa powder and whisk until combined
In a bowl or stand mixer with a whisk attachment, combine sugar, salt, olive oil, eggs, vanilla.
Reduce speed and pour in the cocoa powder mixture.
In a separate container, combine flour and baking soda, and then add to the batter.

Bake in a thin layer on a sheet tray for around 20-25 minutes.  In an 8-inch round cake tin, bake for 30-35 minutes or until a toothpick comes out with moist crumbs and the cake springs back to the touch.
Let cake cool before enjoying. For best results bake the cake 1-2 in advance before serving as the flavors continue to develop.

Creator: alchenny
Name: Chocolate Olive Oil Cake
Description:
based on the NYT recipe by Melissa Clark. This is a fluffy, moist, and complex chocolate cake that I use as part of my dessert course at my pop up restaurant.

(also I'm sorry for this ugly photo okay I tend to eat my cakes before I have the effort to take a photo of them whoopsies.

directions.Direction: Prepare the Gelatin Mixture: In a small bowl, sprinkle 3g of gelatin over 10g of water. Stir to combine. Let it sit for about 5 minutes to bloom.

Heat Half of the Heavy Cream: Pour 125g of heavy cream into a saucepan and add 20g of corn syrup. Heat the mixture over low heat, stirring constantly, until it's warm but not boiling. The corn syrup helps to stabilize the ganache and add a smooth texture, but can be omitted

Melt the White Chocolate: Chop the white chocolate into small pieces for even melting. Once the heavy cream mixture is warm, remove it from the heat and add the chopped white chocolate. Let it sit for a minute to gently melt the chocolate, then stir until the mixture is smooth and homogeneous.

Dissolve the Gelatin: Microwave the bloomed gelatin for about 10 seconds or until it becomes liquid. Watch it closely to avoid overheating. Stir the liquid gelatin into the warm white chocolate mixture until fully incorporated. This step ensures the ganache sets with a smooth, firm texture upon cooling.
Cool the Mixture: Add the rest of the heavy cream to the ganache mixture and stir until completely combined and smooth. Chill the mixture for at least 2 hours, preferably overnight.

Whip the Cream: In a large bowl or stand mixer, whip the chilled cream until soft-stiff peaks form. The consistency of this cream holds soft peaks very well. Be of careful of overwhipping as the cream can over whip easily.

Creator: alchenny
Name: Whipped White Chocolate Ganache
Description:
A simple yet smooth and silky alternative to whipped cream. The addition of the gelatin makes this recipe more stable and easier to pipe. Just be careful not to overwhip!

This recipe was used to top my black sesame mochi cake.

directions.Direction: For the Pate a Choux Dough
Make 1 batch of the pate a choux dough recipe
Using a star tip, pipe small 2-3 inch logs.
Bake the choux for 15 minutes at 425, dropping the temperature to 375 for another 10-15 minutes until the choux is puffed, and golden brown
Set aside to cool while working on the other components
For the Raspberry Chantilly (Whipped Cream)
Melt the white chocolate and 200ml in the microwave or over a double boiler until completely melted and smooth.
Cool to room temperature (ideally rest in fridge overnight)
Blend or mash raspberries to release the juice. Pass this mixture through a fine mesh sieve
In a stand mixer, combine the white chocolate mixture and the remaining cream. Until desired consistency
Pour in raspberry puree and mix until combined
For the Glaze
Melt butter and chocolate in the microwave in 15 second intervals
Combine the chocolate mixture with sugar and water, stirring until well combined
Adjust the consistency of the glaze with more water or powdered sugar
For the Assembly
Poke three holes out of the rounded side of the eclair. Pipe the raspberry chantilly into the cooled eclairs
Top with glaze, and garnish with fresh raspberries

Creator: alchenny
Name: Raspberry Eclair
Description:
A fresh and fruity eclair perfect for the summer! Feel free to fill and frost your eclairs however you desire.

Note: Valrhona raspberry inspiration is quite an expensive ingredient, so feel free to frost with a traditional fondant icing or a substitute with white chocolate, and some pink food coloring. Freeze dried raspberry powder can also be added combined with the powdered sugar to add extra flavor.

directions.Direction: Start with the pate a choux dough recipe, piping into 3-4 inch strips.
Sprinkle with everything bagel seasoning, and bake at 425F (220C) for 10 minutes then 375F (190C) for an additional 15-20 minutes.
For the Salmon Mousse
While the eclairs bake and cool, make the filling. In a food processor, combine cream cheese, smoked salmon, lemon zest, juice, chives, salt and pepper. Blend to combine
Slowly pour in the cream until a light mousse consistency is formed. Transfer the mousse into a piping bag, and let it chill in the fridge until ready to use
For the Assembly
Poke three holes into the rounded side of the now cooled eclairs. Pipe the salmon mousse into each eclair
Garnish with smoked salmon, chives, everything bagel seasoning, and lemon zest
Bon appetit!

Creator: alchenny
Name: Salmon Cream Cheese Eclair
Description:
It's a bagel in French form.

Since pate a choux is neither savory or sweet, the flavor combinations are endless. This is a classic and delicious way to have a salmon cream cheese bagel in an eclair-formed snack.

directions.Direction: Preheat the oven to 425°F (220°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat.

In a medium-sized saucepan, combine the butter, water, sugar and salt. Place the saucepan over medium heat and bring the mixture to a gentle boil. Stir occasionally to ensure the butter is fully melted.

Once the mixture reaches a boil, reduce the heat to low and quickly add the flour all at once. Stir vigorously using a wooden spoon until the mixture forms a smooth, thick dough. Keep stirring for another 1-2 minutes to cook the flour slightly. The dough should come together and pull away from the sides of the saucepan.
Remove the saucepan from the heat and transfer to a stand mixer. Mix the dough on low speed until the dough has cooled slightly
Add the eggs, one at a time, to the slightly cooled dough, beating well after each addition.
Transfer the dough into a piping bag fitted with a large round tip

Pipe the dough onto the prepared baking sheet into desired shapes. For cream puffs, pipe small mounds about 1.5 inches (4 cm) in diameter. For eclairs, pipe long strips about 4 inches (10 cm) in length.

Place the baking sheet in the preheated oven and bake for 15 minutes at 425°F (220°C). Then, lower the oven temperature to 375°F (190°C) and continue baking for an additional 15-20 minutes or until the choux pastries are golden brown and crisp.
Once the choux pastries are done baking, remove them from the oven and make a small slit in each one to release any steam. This will help to keep them crisp.
Let the choux pastries cool completely on a wire rack.

Creator: alchenny
Name: Pate a Choux (Cream Puff Dough)
Description: This is a staple pastry dough recipe for all kinds of classic French pastries from cream puffs, eclairs, paris brest, and more.

directions.Direction: For the Hazelnut Shortcrust Pastry
In a food processor, blitz all hazelnuts (80g) into a fine powder. Be careful not to over blitz as this will release too much oil from the nuts
Add flour, powdered sugar, and salt. Pulse until the hazelnuts have been broken down into a fine crumb.
Add butter and pulse until combined
Add in half egg and pulse until the dough comes together. If the dough is too dry, add a splash of water, little by little.
Wrap in plastic wrap and rest in the fridge for an hour or until the dough becomes firm.
For the Hazelnut Cream
With a mixer or by hand, combine the butter, sugar, hazelnuts, almond powder, and cornstarch together until smooth
Add in egg, beating to emulsify.
Optional: add additional flavoring to the filling with a bit of lemon zest, ground ginger, or ground cinnamon
For the Assembly
Preheat oven to 350F/180C
Thinly slice two peaches or any fruit of your choice
Roll out pastry dough into a thin circle over a piece of parchment paper
Spread a layer of hazelnut cream overtop of the dough, ensuring to leave a 1.5in border along the sides of the dough
Place fruit on top of the hazelnut cream. Fold the edges of the dough using the parchment paper.
Combine the remaining egg with a splash of milk or water. Brush the egg wash over the sides of the pastry and sprinkle with turbinado or course sugar
Bake at 350F/180C for 30-40 minutes until the crust is golden and the hazelnut cream is slightly puffed.

Creator: alchenny
Name: Hazelnut Peach Galette
Description:
A twist on an already not so french classic. This galette is a slightly fancier version of a simple and rustic dessert. 

Peaches can be substituted for a wide variety of stone fruits (cherries, apricots, nectarines, plums) or other fruits that pair well with hazelnuts.

directions.Direction: Brown butter in a sauce pan over medium heat. Once butter is to desired color, remove from heat and let cool
In a food processor (or by hand) lightly combine flour, almond flour, and sugar. Add egg whites and mix until combined.
While mixing, slowly pour in cooled browned butter.
Add salt, lemon zest, and grated ginger
Pour batter into a container and let it rest in the fridge for at least 2 hours (preferably overnight).
Preheat oven to 350F/180C
Pour batter into an 7-8 inch cake mold (you can also make individual sizes in a mini muffin tray or other small molds). Top with blackberries and plums, or fruits of your choice.
Pour it into the mold and place in the oven for 30-40 minutes until the top is golden brown and the middle is fully cooked through
Enjoy!

Creator: alchenny
Name: Blackberry Plum Financier cake
Description:
Traditionally, financier's are served as small little tea cakes. If you're too lazy for small individual portions take the delicious batter and make it into a larger cake.

Mix up the flavors with your favorite fruits and spices!

directions.Direction: For the Poached Pears
In a small saucepan, combine water, sugar, honey, and the juice of one lemon. (this is the step where you would add other spices or flavors)
Place pears in the syrup and simmer for 5 minutes or until soft (let pears continue to soak while making the other components)
For the Almond Cream
Combine softened butter and sugar together, add almond flour and continue to beat until all combined.
Optional: add miso paste and almond extract for additional flavor
Add eggs one at a time until cream is smooth. Pour into a piping bag and let the cream chill in the fridge until ready to use.
For the Tart Shell
Preheat oven to 350F/180C

Roll out dough to a 0.5cm thickness and large enough to cover a 16cm tart ring. Line tart ring with the dough, pushing the down into the side and into the corner. Cut off excess dough and chill in freezer for at least 10 minutes
Repeat with the second half of dough.
Pre-bake the tart shells until a light golden brown for about 20-25 minutes.
Combine egg yolk and milk to create an eggwash.
Remove tart shells from oven and allow to cool slightly. Remove tart shells from the ring. Smooth out any bumps with a microplane and brush the outsides with egg wash.
Return to the oven for 5-7 mintues until the egg is cooked through, shiny, and golden brown. Let cool slightly before adding filling
For the Assembly
Pipe almond cream into tart shell, filling the tart up around 2/3 of the way full.
Remove pears from the poaching liquid. Slice halves and cut thinly.
Place 4 sliced pear halves into the almond cream. Optionally, top with sliced almonds
Bake in the oven at 350F/180C for 25-30 minutes until the almond cream is golden brown and is no longer liquidly.
Remove from the oven and cool before enjoying. Top with powdered sugar if desired

Creator: alchenny
Name: Almond Pear Tart (aka Tarte Bourdaloue)
Description:
I used to buy these frozen at trader joe's all the time, so somehow this french classic is very nostalgic. 

Note: This is such an ugly photo oh ma god sorry fam
Notes: You can used tinned pears instead, but I prefer the flavor of making my own poached pears. This not only allows you to control the sweetness, but also allows you to infuse a little bit more flavor such as lemon peel, ginger, cinnamon etc.

directions.Direction: In a bowl, mix together all-purpose flour, baking powder, pumpkin pie spice, and salt.
In a separate bowl, mix eggs, sugar, honey, pumpkin puree, and vanilla extract together
Gently fold in melted butter into the batter until just combined.
Pour batter into a piping bag, and chill in the fridge for 1 hour
Preheat your oven to 190°C (375°F).
Grease and lightly flour the madeleine pan
Spoon the batter into the prepared madeleine pan, filling each mold to about three-quarters.
Bake for 10-12 minutes, or until the edges are golden brown and the centers spring back when lightly touched.
Allow to cool for a few minutes in the pan, then transfer to a wire rack.
Once cooled, dust with powdered sugar before serving.

Creator: alchenny
Name: Pumpkin Madeleine Recipe
Description:
There is never enough pumpkin spice. Thank you.

Many ~american~ madeleine recipes fail to stress the importance of chilling your batter. This results in a lovely little hump on the back of the madeleine.

Because of the extra mositure in the pumpkin. This batter kinda has a small hump. Does that mean this is a bad madeleine? You be the judge of that.

directions.Direction: In a small saucepan, melt butter over medium heat. Continue cooking the butter until the milk solids brown. Remove from heat and let cool slightly
In a stand mixer or by hand, combine cool brown butter, sugar, molasses, egg yolk, and pumpkin puree. Mix until well combined
In a separate bowl, mix together the dry ingredients–– flour, pumpkin pie spice, cinnamon, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.
Add the dry ingredients into the wet, and mix until just combined.
Add chocolate chips or chopped chocolate to the dough. Mix on slow until just combined.
Portion cookies out into balls on a baking sheet. (I make 75g portions, making ~10 cookies)
Optional but highly recommended: chill in the fridge for 1-2. This ensures a thicker and softer cookie
Preheat oven to 350F/180C
Bake cookies for 13-15 minutes until the edges begin to brown and the middle is set. Remove from the heat
Optional: reshape each cookie before they are completely cooled and top with flakey salt.
Let cool slightly (or don't, I don't blame you), and enjoy! Bon appetit!

Creator: alchenny
Name: Pumpkin Chocolate Chip Cookies (NOT CAKEY)
Description:
These are not your mom's cakey pumpkin chocolate chip cookie. These are my kind of chewy chocolate chip cookie that also happens to be perfect perfect for the fall season.

Of course this recipe includes pumpkin pie spice for a classic fall warmth but more importantly, my favorite ingredient: brown butter.

Note: I prefer to make cookies with molasses and white sugar as opposed to buying brown sugar. You can substitute with 75g white sugar and 175g brown sugar
Notes: Note: I prefer to make cookies with molasses and white sugar as opposed to buying brown sugar. You can substitute with 75g white sugar and 175g brown sugar

ingredients.Name: large egg + 1 additional egg yolk, at room temperature
Maldon sea salt, for sprinkling on top

directions.Direction: Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C) and line a baking sheet with parchment paper.

In a medium saucepan, melt the butter over medium heat. Continue cooking the butter, stirring frequently, until it starts to foam and turn a golden brown color. This process will take about 5-7 minutes. Be careful not to burn the butter; once it turns brown, remove it from the heat immediately and transfer it to a heatproof bowl. Place two ice cubes into the hot butter. Allow the browned butter to cool and the ice cubes to melt.
In a separate bowl, whisk together the all-purpose flour, baking soda, instant coffee, and salt. Set aside.
In a stand mixer, combine the brown sugar and granulated sugar with the slightly cooled brown butter. Mix until well combined and smooth.
Beat in the egg, egg yolk, and vanilla until well combined
On low speed, gradually add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients. Mix until just combined
Gently fold in all the mix ins until they are evenly distributed throughout the dough.
Chill the dough in the fridge for at least 2 hours, or up to 12-24 hours. (This prevents excessive spreading and allows for the flavors to develop)

After chilling, remove the dough from the refrigerator. Using a cookie scoop or your hands, form 1.5-2 tablespoon-sized balls of dough and place them on the prepared baking sheet, leaving some space between each cookie.
Once the dough is chilled, preheat the over to 350F (180C). Bake the cookies in the preheated oven for 10-12 minutes or until the edges are golden brown and the centers are still slightly soft.
Remove the baking sheet from the oven and let the cookies cool on the sheet for 5 minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.
Bon appetit

Creator: alchenny
Name: Chocolate Espresso Passion Fruit Cookie
Description:
This is a really classic flavor combination especially in France, but now 

Recipe adapted from ambitious kitchen

ingredients.Name: peanut butter milk chocolate (I used Mr Beast Deez Nuts)

directions.Direction: In a large mixing bowl or stand mixer, combine the melted unsalted butter, sugar, and molasses. Mix well until the sugar is fully incorporated.
Add the large egg and egg yolk to the butter-sugar mixture. Mix until smooth and well combined.
In a separate bowl, combine the all-purpose flour, bread flour, baking soda, and salt.
Gradually add the dry ingredient mixture to the wet ingredients, stirring until a thick cookie dough forms.
Chop the peanut butter milk chocolate into small chunks and gently fold them into the cookie dough.
Carefully fold in the frozen raspberries, being mindful not to crush them completely.
Use a cookie scoop to portion the dough into balls of around 75 grams each and place them on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat.
Cover the baking sheet with plastic wrap or aluminum foil and refrigerate the portioned cookie dough for 1-2 hours until firm.
Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C).
Arrange the chilled cookie dough portions on a prepared baking sheet, leaving space between each portion to allow for spreading.
Bake in the preheated oven for 15-17 minutes or until the edges are golden brown and the centers are set.
Remove from the oven and reshape using a cookie cutter. Let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for a few minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.

Creator: alchenny
Name: Milk Chocolate Peanut Butter & Raspberry Cookie
Description:
This is a peanut butter and jelly inspired cookie because as an American, this is my roman empire.

This cookie uses frozen raspberries and peanut butter filled milk chocolate for a nice contrast of fruity and rich flavors.

ingredients.Name: milk chocolate (I used Feastables milk chocolate)

directions.Direction: In a large mixing bowl, combine the melted unsalted butter, sugar, and molasses. Mix well until the sugar is fully incorporated.
Add the large egg and egg yolk to the butter-sugar mixture, followed by the vanilla extract and white miso paste. Mix until smooth and well combined.
In a separate bowl, sift together the all-purpose flour, bread flour, malt powder, baking soda, and salt.
Gradually add the dry ingredient mixture to the wet ingredients, stirring until a thick cookie dough forms.
Gently fold in the chopped milk chocolate until evenly distributed throughout the dough.
Use a cookie scoop to portion the dough into balls of around 75 grams each and place them on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat.
Cover the baking sheet with plastic wrap or aluminum foil and refrigerate the portioned cookie dough for 1-2 hours until firm.
Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C).
Arrange the chilled cookie dough portions on a prepared baking sheet, leaving space between each portion to allow for spreading.
Bake in the preheated oven for 12-15 minutes or until the edges are golden brown and the centers are set.
Remove from the oven and reshape with a cookie cutter or mug. Let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for a few minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.

Creator: alchenny
Name: Malted Milk Chocolate Chip Cookie
Description:
Yes these are minute adjustments to your good old chocolate chip cookie just for the sake of being quirky. Does the malt and miso make this cookie better? You be the judge. 

They're chewy. They're cute. They're great. Flakey salt is mandatory.

ingredients.Name: egg (separated into egg yolk and white)

directions.Direction: For the Soy Sauce Toffee
In a medium saucepan over medium heat, combine the brown sugar, butter, soy sauce, and vanilla. Stir continuously until the butter is melted and the mixture starts to bubble.
Place candy thermometer into sauce pan. Cook toffee over medium heat until 290F-300F, or the "hard crack" stage. The toffee should have a very dark amber color (from the soy sauce).
Pour toffee onto a baking sheet lined with parchment paper or a silicone mat. Allow to cool completely.
Break or chop cooled toffee into fine pieces.
For the Butter Cookie
In a large mixing bowl, cream together the softened butter, miso paste, and icing sugar until pale and fluffy. About 3-4 minutes with an electric mixer on medium speed.
Add in the flour and mix until there are no large lumps of butter.
Add in the egg yolk and mix until combined. The texture should still be quite sandy.
Pour dough out onto counter top and finish combining by hand. Smush the dough on the counter to remove any remaining lumps.
Add in crushed toffee bits.
Split the dough into two balls. Roll each half of dough into a log shape (about 1.5inch in diameter).
Wrap in plastic wrap, and chill in the refrigerator for at least 1 hour, so dough is firm.
In a separate bowl, mix the turbinado (or coarse sugar) with the furikake.
Remove dough from the fridge and unwrap from the plastic wrap. Brush the outside with the egg white, and coat the outside of the log with the furikake sugar mixture.
Cut into slices approximately 1/4 inch thick.
Place the slices on the prepared baking sheet and bake for about 12-15 minutes, or until the edges are just starting to turn golden.
Allow the cookies to cool on the baking sheet for a few minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.

Creator: alchenny
Name: Soy Sauce Furikake Cookies
Description:
This is what happens when you bake too many cookies and also desperately want poke.

Based of french sablé cookies, this recipe adds a few other savory elements to transform these butter cookies into a salty and sweet combo that you never asked for! But I promise you they are so oddly delicious

Note: I used the Nori Komi Furikake, which is a mix of roasted seaweed, sesame seeds, salt, and sugar. This is the simplest furikake seasoning out there, which I feel compliments the rest of flavors in the cookie. Feel free to use other flavors of furikake if you're feeling funky.

Epic video filmed with Philip Lemoine in NYC

directions.Direction: In a bowl, combine all-purpose flour, cornstarch, baking powder, and salt. Whisk together. Set aside.
In a separate bowl, add light brown sugar and granulated sugar. Whisk together with a hand mixer on medium speed until light and airy. While whisking, slowly stream in melted butter butter.
Add in the eggs one at a time followed by the egg yolks.
Once the butter sugar, and egg mixture is smooth, switch to a rubber spatula and fold in the dry ingredients until the dough forms.
Add in rough chopped walnuts and chopped chocolate. Mix until combined. Cover and let the dough rest in the fridge for 30 minutes.
Remove from fridge. Scoop out a large dough ball. Weigh each dough ball out to 6oz and place on a parchment lined baking sheet. About ten equal sized balls.
Cover with plastic wrap, and let chill in the fridge at least 12 hours, up to 48.
Preheat the oven to 425F (400F convection).

Remove cookie dough from fridge. Space each cookie about 2-3 inches apart from each other on a parchment lined baking tray. Bake for 10-15 minutes. Or until the edges are golden, but the middle is still slightly gooey. Set tray on a wire rack to cool at least 15 minutes before serving.

Creator: alchenny
Name: Chocolate Chip Walnut Cookies (Levain copycat)
Description:
Growing up, these were my favorite little treat back when there was one levain bakery on the Upper West Side. Fast forward a decade later, I feel like it is my duty as cookie baker to recreate them all for you.

Tips:
- With so much chocolate in this recipe I recommend using a high quality chocolate chip, or using chopping up a bar
- You must refrigerate the dough. With the large amount of fat in the dough, the cookies need time to rest and come together.

ingredients.Name: (12 Tbsp) unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled*

directions.Direction: Whisk together flour, baking soda, cornstarch, ground ginger, and salt in a bowl.
In a separate bowl or stand mixer, combine the melted butter with brown sugar until smooth. Beat in the egg and vanilla extract. Grate the fresh ginger and add it to the mixture.
Gradually mix the dry ingredients into the wet mixture until well combined
Portion dough into balls (around 2 tablespoons each) and place on a baking tray. Chill the balls of dough for at least 1 hour or overnight
Preheat your oven to 350°F (180°C) and line baking sheets with parchment paper.
Place lemon curd into piping bag for easier use.

Create a dent in the ball and fill with about 1/4 teaspoon of lemon curd. Re-roll the dough back into a ball, and roll each ball in granulated sugar. Place them on the prepared baking sheets, spaced apart.
Bake until the edges are set but the centers are still soft, about 10-12 minutes.
Let them cool on the baking sheet for a few minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely.

Creator: alchenny
Name: Ginger Lemon Cookies
Description: My mom loves to make me a hot cup of ginger lemon tea. This is what I imagine it would be like in cookie form if she ever baked me something
Notes:
For extra ginger flavor, increase the amount of fresh grated ginger.
For best results, use homemade lemon curd for a fresh and zesty flavor.

ingredients.Name: (12 Tbsp) unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled*

directions.Direction: Zest orange and lemon (and fresh herbs in using) into the sugar to release their oils and produce the best flavor
Whisk together flour, baking soda, cornstarch,  and salt in a bowl.
In a separate bowl or stand mixer, combine the melted butter with citrus sugar until smooth. Beat in the egg and vanilla extract.
Gradually mix the dry ingredients into the wet mixture until well combined
Portion dough into balls (around 2 tablespoons each) and place on a baking tray. Chill the balls of dough for at least 1 hour or overnight
Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C) and line baking sheets with parchment paper.
Roll the dough into balls, then roll each ball in granulated sugar. Place them on the prepared baking sheets, spaced apart.
Bake until the edges are set but the centers are still soft, about 10-12 minutes.
Let them cool on the baking sheet for a few minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely.

Creator: alchenny
Name: Chewy Citrus Sugar Cookies
Description:
Bakery sugar cookies. With citrus (no spice) and everything nice!

Add some herbs like rosemary or thyme for a fun variation!

directions.Direction: Preheat your oven to 175°C (350°F). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat.
In a medium-sized bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, and salt. Set aside.
In a large mixing bowl, cream together the butter and granulated sugar until light and fluffy, about 2-3 minutes. You can use a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment or a hand mixer.
Add the egg and egg yolk, to the butter-sugar mixture. Beat until well combined, scraping down the sides of the bowl as needed.
Gradually add the dry ingredient mixture to the wet ingredients, mixing until just combined. Be careful not to overmix.

Divide the dough into three equal parts.To one part, add the freeze-dried strawberry powder and mix until well incorporated.To the second part, add the gochujang paste and mix until well incorporated.
Scoop dough using a cookie scoop or tablespoon and place onto the prepared baking sheet, spacing them about 2 inches apart.
Bake in the preheated oven for 10-12 minutes, or until the edges are lightly golden and the centers are set.
Allow the cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.

Creator: alchenny
Name: Strawberry Gochujang Cookies
Description:
bro for how many times I've made these why don't I have a better photo of it.

I was inspired by a jar of strawberry gochujang paste that I found in the grocery store and the viral neopolitan cookies that always float around Instagram.
Notes:
Feel free to adjust the amount of gochujang in the recipe for your desired spice and umami level. The type of gochujang paste used really effects the flavor of the cookies. Try and aim for a sweeter paste as opposed to a very savory one.
If you can't find a sweet gochujang paste, reduce the gochujang to 10g and add 10g of honey for balance. 

The flavor of the cookies slightly changes after baking and resting. Personally I think they taste better the next day.
